title: List<T> (The Flexible Container)
simplifierConcept:
Remember arrays? They're like a bookshelf with fixed slots - you can't add more books if it's full!

A LIST is like a magical expanding shelf! You can:
• Add items anytime (shelf grows automatically!)
• Remove items (shelf shrinks!)
• Insert items in the middle
• Check if an item exists

Lists are DYNAMIC - they change size as needed. The <T> syntax (like List<int>) means 'List of what type?' Just like arrays, all items must be the same type, but unlike arrays, you can grow and shrink them!

Think of a grocery list app: You add items ('milk'), remove items when bought, and the list grows/shrinks automatically. You wouldn't use a fixed array for that - you'd use a List!

Lists are THE most common collection in C#. When in doubt, use a List!

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: List<T> where T is the type. List<string> = list of strings, List<int> = list of integers. The angle brackets specify what type is stored!
Adds an item to the END of the list. The list automatically expands to fit! add() is THE most common list operation.
Removes the FIRST occurrence of this item from the list. If the item isn't found, nothing happens (no error).
Like array's .Length but for lists! Use .Count to get the number of items. NOTE: It's Count not Length!
Returns true if the item exists in the list, false otherwise. Great for checking before adding or removing!

challenge.instructions:
Create a player inventory system!

1. Create a List<string> called 'inventory'
2. Add these items: 'Sword', 'Shield', 'Potion'
3. Display the count of items
4. Check if inventory Contains 'Potion' - if yes, display 'Potion ready!'
5. Remove 'Potion' (it was used!)
6. Add 'Gold Coin'
7. Use a foreach loop to display all remaining items

Remember: using System.Collections.Generic; at the top!
challenge.hint: Create: List<string> list = new List<string>(); Add: list.Add("item"); Remove: list.Remove("item"); Check: list.Contains("item")
commonStickingPoints: Forgetting using statement: List needs 'using System.Collections.Generic;' at the top! Without it, C# doesn't know what List is.
Using .Length instead of .Count: Arrays use .Length, Lists use .Count! list.Length doesn't exist!
Forgetting <T>: Just 'List' is wrong! Must specify type: List<int>, List<string>, etc. The angle brackets are REQUIRED!
Index out of range on dynamic lists: If you remove items, the Count changes! Always loop with i < list.Count, not a hardcoded number.
